There are just too many factors and regulations that already go into high school sports to try to do it at the youth level.
Thank you for your understanding.

Coach Corson High School Football Coach

Covid update: May 21st
Yesterday the Governor paved the way for some limited reopening of our facilities as well as giving the green light to baseball and softball resuming June 1st. Please understand that her proclamation does not allow any of our grounds to be reopened until June 1st, including the softball and baseball fields, and does not reopen our playground facilities at this time.

We ask for your cooperation in being patient and helping us comply with the regulations. As a District we will not reopen any facilities until we feel we have the ability to meet the guidelines we have been given by the Department of Education. We are confident we can do this by June 1st at our baseball and softball facilities and will work diligently to meet the requirements in other areas as well when we are allowed.

We all remember those teachers who truly had an impact on our lives❤️ Happy Teacher Appreciation Week to the teachers out there who always put the kids first 🍎 You are making a difference, even if the results aren’t immediate or visible 👏🏼

GR teachers are spending time not only providing learning opportunities for their students but also taking time to delve into their professional learning. This course was specifically designed to assist teachers in providing learning to their students in an online setting. Teachers are also spending time aligning their Iowa Core Standards to their curriculum for each course/subject area they teach. This helps our district keep track of what students are learning at each grade level. We appreciate all of the hard work and time they are putting in!!

***ATTENTION: All students in DMACC classes.***
Attached you will find a document that outlines some of the DMACC policies that have been amended for the spring 2020 semester. We realize that there is a lot of concern amongst students with having to move instruction online, so we are trying to be flexible and provide additional options.

The two policies addressed in the handout include extensions to the drop dates and also the option to let students choose a Pass/Fail grade after the semester ends. I am asking students to contact me before they choose the pass/fail option as some courses/programs will not accept these grades for pre-requisites or for the program. A quick example of that would be our nursing program requires that students must pass each class with a C or better, so a P grade would not qualify students to have met that minimum.

MathCounts is a national math enrichment and competition program. Glidden-Ralston's very own Elizabeth Lloyd progressed to the State Competition! At the State level, Elizabeth participated in a Sprint Round which focused on accuracy of solving problems. Next it was the Target Round which featured multi-step problems that engaged Elizabeth in mathematical reasoning and problem solving processes. Her final round was the Team Round where team members interact to solve problems. At this point, the top 10 students were determined and competed in an oral, fast-paced competition to determine the top four individuals to represent the state of Iowa as a team at the National MathCounts Competition.

Way to go Elizabeth!

A STUDY OF ANCIENT EGYPT

Last fall, Ms. Roose and Luke decided to mummify a cornish game hen after studying ancient Egypt. First, they "bathed" the Cornish hen with alcohol to get rid of any bacteria. Next, they created a mummifying mixture of equal parts salt and baking soda. They reverently placed the "princess" in the bowl of the mixture and completely covered her with the mixture. After 9 days, they removed the old mixture and added fresh "natron" into the bowl and covered her once more. She remained there for 4 months, just to make sure she was completely mummified. They used toilet paper for her wrappings and created a sarcophagus for her. Ancient Egyptians would say she is now in the afterlife, enjoying green fields and ample food sources.

The CDC (Centers of Disease Control) recommends to keep your child home from school for at least 24 hours after their fever is gone. The fever should be gone without the use of fever-reducing medication.

The number one way to prevent the spread of illness is to wash your hands!!

Jessie remarked,” It's always great to see our school being awarded scholarships within the community. I’m very excited and thankful!.”

Way to go Gals!!!

Makerspace aka Genius Hour aka Passion Projects!

We are encouraging students who have a passion to learn and use their creativity to explore new things that they don’t use in a typical classroom. Students in grades 4th to 6th meet once a cycle to pursue ideas, plan a prototype, and take it to the Makerspace Room. Last spring some students created a cool chair and even made a bed for their dog. Kim Flanagan had this to say, I love the excitement of kids looking to do a project. Using their imagination is great! My hope is the community will keep helping in the future by donating random supplies and projects. (Sandpaper, electrical gadgets, etc)”. The classroom teachers who help/guide students are Mrs. Rath, Mr. Corson, Mrs. Peters, and Ms. Pauley.

Mr. Thelin had the opportunity to video a few students this week and see what they were interested in doing..

G-R HONORS VETERANS

Today G-R hosted the annual Veterans Day breakfast and school wide assembly. The students look forward to this day and the chance to say thank you to our local veterans. They were treated to breakfast and 6th graders displayed table decorations from art class and took the opportunity to visit and get to know the veterans. First graders led the Pledge of Allegiance and the band played the National Anthem at the assembly. Mr. Doug Cunningham shared the history of the American Legion as they celebrate 100 years. Mr. Cunningham served in the US Marine Corps from 1988-2017 during the Global War on Terrorism/Persian Gulf. Mr. Ed Rohner presented Esta Raasch with a picture of a reconnaissance aircraft painted with all the names of MIA and POWs from the Vietnam War which included her brother, Donald Sparks, a 1964 G-R graduate.

TO ALL OUR VETERANS - THANK YOU FOR YOUR SERVICE
